name: Mixed recyclables, at collection, dropoff center
description:
This attributional unit process LCI represents the estimated fuel use (transport requirements) per unit weight (or volume) of mixed household recyclables to a dropoff center. The LCI study was conducted by Franklin Associates, Ltd. and sponsored jointly by NAPCOR, the American Chemistry Council (ACC), the Association of Postconsumer Plastic Recyclers (APR), and the PET Resin Association (PETRA). Using life cycle inventory (LCI) methodology, the study determines and quantifies the energy requirements, solid wastes, and atmospheric and waterborne emissions for the processes required to collect postconsumer PET and HDPE packaging, sort and separate the material, and reprocess it into clean recycled resin.

Important note: although most of the data in the US LCI database has undergone some sort of review, the database as a whole has not yet undergone a formal validation process. Please email comments to lci@nrel.gov.
category: 56: Administrative and Support and Waste Management and Remediation Services/5621: Waste Collection

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data compiled 2010 from most recent sources
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Typical person transport of mixed recyclables
processDocumentation.inventoryMethodDescription: Attributional; data sets for the three recycling unit processes (collection, sorting/separation, reclaimer operations) were linked to cover the full sequence of processing steps required to produce recycled resins  gate-to-gate results; for cradle-to-gate LCI of recycled resin, the practitioner needs to make decision about virgin resin burdens associated with the postconsumer products that are feedstocks to recycling. Recycling occurs in the context of a product made from resin; use and end-of-life management of the material will depend on the product in which it is used
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription:
Fuel use by consumers delivering household recyclables to a dropoff center was estimated based on following assumptions:
• 16.9 pounds of household recyclables generated per week (EPA MSW report)
• Recyclables dropped off every other week (ERG assumption)
• Distance driven: 10 miles (EPA MSW Decision Support Tool default value)
• Fuel economy of personal vehicle used for trip: 20 mpg (MSW DST default)
• Percent of trips that are dedicated trips: 50% (MSW DST default; remainder of trips are assumed to have a different primary purpose so that dropoff of recyclables is incidental)

Using these factors, the gallons of gasoline used per thousand pounds of material delivered to a recycling center is calculated as 1000 lb/(16.9 lb/wk * 2 wks/trip) x 10 miles/trip, divided by 20 pg x 50% dedicated trips = 7.4 gallons per thousand pounds. 

NOTE (March 2021): 7.4 gal/1000 lb value (~0.062 L) gasoline consumption in passenger vehicle CUTOFF was replaced with linkage to 'Transport, passenger car, gasoline powered'; March 2021 by USLCI Data Curator; conversion to ~ 0.96 p*km based on:
• 9773.94 km / 1000 L fuel or distance traveled by gasoline-powered vehicles per total energy consumption based on total km & gasoline LHV  from MOVES2010a. Version 2010/08/26. Developed by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, August 2010, and
• 1.59 passengers per vehicle (average) statistic based on Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Transportation Energy Data Book, 29 ed. U.S. Department of Energy, June 2010.
processDocumentation.completenessDescription:
TREATMENT OF MISSING ENVIRONMENTAL DATA
Elementary flows are cut-off at less than 1% based on environmental relevance.

TREATMENT OF MISSING TECHNOSPHERE DATA
Intermediate flows are cut-off at less than 1% based on environmental relevance. Capital equipment is not included in this unit process.

MASS BALANCE
Based on wastes removed at Material Recycling Facility (MR)F, the collected material contains about 0.087 kg waste per kg of usable material. Weight of material in this unit process still includes waste and usable materials since all of it is transported to the dropoff center.
processDocumentation.dataSelectionDescription: Estimates on fuel consumption for average delivery by consumers to dropoff center were converted to person*kilometers gasoline-powered passenger vehicle transport to eliminate the 'Gasoline, used in personal vehicle' CUTOFF inputs (i.e., replaced by 'Transport, passenger car, gasoline powered' by USLCI Data Curator, March 2021.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Assumtions and calculations described in Modeling Constants.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS
The system boundary includes the transport of household recyclables to a dropoff center.

DATA COLLECTION
Assumptions and calculations are described in Modeling Constants and the supporting documentation.

UNCERTAINTY ESTIMATION
No uncertainty estimations were included.
processDocumentation.dataCollectionDescription: Data compiled 2010 from most recent sources

sources.name: Franklin Associates (2011) LCI HDPE & PET Recycled Resin

reviews.details: The LCI study was conducted by Franklin Associates, Ltd. and sponsored jointly by NAPCOR, the American Chemistry Council (ACC), the Association of Postconsumer Plastic Recyclers (APR), and the PET Resin Association (PETRA). Using life cycle inventory (LCI) methodology, the study determines and quantifies the energy requirements, solid wastes, and atmospheric and waterborne emissions for the processes required to collect postconsumer PET and HDPE packaging, sort and separate the material, and reprocess it into clean recycled resin. The data has had a partial critical review by internal parties.

processDocumentation.intendedApplication:
These data are an update to the 2010 dataset with the same process name; update includes elimination of transport CUTOFF and conversion of fuel consumption to p*km linked to USLCI passenger transport inventory.

"Accounting, with system-external interactions" - The intended application is a purely descriptive accounting / documentation of the analysed system including existing interactions with other systems in the LCI model.
processDocumentation.projectDescription: LIFE CYCLE INVENTORY OF 100% POSTCONSUMER HDPE AND PET RECYCLED RESIN FROM POSTCONSUMER CONTAINERS AND PACKAGING PREPARED FOR THE PLASTICS DIVISION OF THE AMERICAN CHEMISTRY COUNCIL, INC. THE ASSOCIATION OF POSTCONSUMER PLASTIC RECYCLERS (APR), THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR PET CONTAINER RESOURCES(NAPCOR), AND THE PET RESIN ASSOCIATION (PETRA) BY FRANKLIN ASSOCIATES, A DIVISION OF ERG PRAIRIE VILLAGE, KANSAS JANUARY 19, 2011.
